evidence.excerpt: Vendor may modify prices, discounts, or product offerings no more than twice in any rolling twelve (12) month period and only upon at least sixty (60) days' prior written notice... all bona fide quotations issued within sixty (60) days prior to the effective date remain valid at the prior pricing
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 30-day notice creates 'margin squeeze and quote invalidation'. Amendments address all GT elements: extends notice to 60 days, limits frequency to 2x/year, adds quote protection.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Vendor may modify prices, discounts, or product offerings no more than twice in any rolling twelve (12) month period and only upon at least sixty (60) days' prior written notice... all bona fide quotations issued within sixty (60) days prior to the effective date remain valid at the prior pricing
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Vendor may modify prices, discounts, or product offerings no more than twice in any rolling twelve (12) month period and only upon at least sixty (60) days' prior written notice... all bona fide quotations issued within sixty (60) days prior to the effective date remain valid at the prior pricing

gt_evaluations.issue: Unilateral price and discount changes with short notice

evidence.excerpt: Reseller may terminate this Agreement for convenience at any time after the first anniversary of the Effective Date upon sixty (60) days' prior written notice to Vendor
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'locks Reseller in for full term'. Amendment adds TfC right after first year with 60-day notice - directly addresses GT concern.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Reseller may terminate this Agreement for convenience at any time after the first anniversary of the Effective Date upon sixty (60) days' prior written notice to Vendor
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Reseller may terminate this Agreement for convenience at any time after the first anniversary of the Effective Date upon sixty (60) days' prior written notice to Vendor

gt_evaluations.issue: No termination for convenience during Term

evidence.excerpt: EXCEPT FOR LIABILITY ARISING FROM A PARTY'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS, BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY, OR WILLFUL MISCONDUCT, THE TOTAL AGGREGATE LIABILITY OF EITHER PARTY... SHALL NOT EXCEED THE TOTAL AMOUNTS PAID AND PAYABLE
evidence.reasoning: Partial detection: Pathfinder addresses carve-outs (indemnity, confidentiality, misconduct) but does NOT increase the 12-month cap amount. GT expects increase to 24+ months or minimum floor. Making cap mutual is useful but doesn't address the quantum issue.
evidence.judge_reasoning: EXCEPT FOR LIABILITY ARISING FROM A PARTY'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS, BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY, OR WILLFUL MISCONDUCT, THE TOTAL AGGREGATE LIABILITY OF EITHER PARTY... SHALL NOT EXCEED THE TOTAL AMOUNTS PAID AND PAYABLE
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: EXCEPT FOR LIABILITY ARISING FROM A PARTY'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS, BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY, OR WILLFUL MISCONDUCT, THE TOTAL AGGREGATE LIABILITY OF EITHER PARTY... SHALL NOT EXCEED THE TOTAL AMOUNTS PAID AND PAYABLE

evidence.excerpt: the Products and the use thereof in accordance with this Agreement and the EULA do not and will not infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party... EXCLUDING VENDOR'S OBLIGATIONS UNDER SECTION 14 (INDEMNIFICATION)
evidence.reasoning: Risk table 11.1 correctly identifies missing non-infringement warranty; 11.2 identifies broad disclaimer. Amendments add IP warranty and carve out indemnification from disclaimer.
evidence.judge_reasoning: the Products and the use thereof in accordance with this Agreement and the EULA do not and will not infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party... EXCLUDING VENDOR'S OBLIGATIONS UNDER SECTION 14 (INDEMNIFICATION)
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: the Products and the use thereof in accordance with this Agreement and the EULA do not and will not infringe any intellectual property rights of any third party... EXCLUDING VENDOR'S OBLIGATIONS UNDER SECTION 14 (INDEMNIFICATION)

evidence.excerpt: Vendor shall not knowingly undercut Reseller's quoted pricing for a registered sales opportunity for a period of six (6) months after registration, and (b) Vendor shall establish a commercially reasonable lead-registration program
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'risk of channel conflict and price erosion'. Amendment adds lead registration and price protection - directly addresses GT concern about Reseller investment protection.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Vendor shall not knowingly undercut Reseller's quoted pricing for a registered sales opportunity for a period of six (6) months after registration, and (b) Vendor shall establish a commercially reasonable lead-registration program
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Vendor shall not knowingly undercut Reseller's quoted pricing for a registered sales opportunity for a period of six (6) months after registration, and (b) Vendor shall establish a commercially reasonable lead-registration program

gt_evaluations.issue: Non-exclusive appointment with Vendor direct sales

evidence.excerpt: Late payments bear interest at the lesser of one percent (1%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies '1.5% monthly interest is 18% APR, high in some jurisdictions'. Amendment reduces to 1% and caps at legal max - addresses GT concern about above-market rate.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Late payments bear interest at the lesser of one percent (1%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Late payments bear interest at the lesser of one percent (1%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law

evidence.excerpt: Vendor may establish and modify credit limits for Reseller upon not less than fifteen (15) days' prior written notice, and shall engage in good-faith discussion... Vendor may require reasonable pre-payment only if Reseller exceeds the then-current credit limits or has undisputed past-due balances exceeding thirty (30) days
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'may cripple Reseller's ability to fulfill deals'. Amendment adds notice period, good-faith discussion, and limits prepayment to undisputed amounts.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Vendor may establish and modify credit limits for Reseller upon not less than fifteen (15) days' prior written notice, and shall engage in good-faith discussion... Vendor may require reasonable pre-payment only if Reseller exceeds the then-current credit limits or has undisputed past-due balances exceeding thirty (30) days
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Vendor may establish and modify credit limits for Reseller upon not less than fifteen (15) days' prior written notice, and shall engage in good-faith discussion... Vendor may require reasonable pre-payment only if Reseller exceeds the then-current credit limits or has undisputed past-due balances exceeding thirty (30) days

gt_evaluations.issue: Vendor can require prepayment on credit issues

evidence.excerpt: End User information (limited to company name, industry, and country), and aggregate pipeline data, all of which shall be deemed Reseller Confidential Information under Section 10 and used by Vendor solely for internal analytics
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'no confidentiality carve-out' and 'could enable Vendor to go direct'. Amendment limits scope and adds confidentiality protection.
evidence.judge_reasoning: End User information (limited to company name, industry, and country), and aggregate pipeline data, all of which shall be deemed Reseller Confidential Information under Section 10 and used by Vendor solely for internal analytics
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: End User information (limited to company name, industry, and country), and aggregate pipeline data, all of which shall be deemed Reseller Confidential Information under Section 10 and used by Vendor solely for internal analytics

gt_evaluations.issue: Sales reports require End User information

evidence.excerpt: EXCEPT WITH RESPECT TO (i) A PARTY'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS, (ii) A BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY, OR (iii) A PARTY'S WILLFUL MISCONDUCT OR GROSS NEGLIGENCE
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'no carve-outs for indemnity, confidentiality, or willful misconduct'. Amendment adds all GT-expected carve-outs.
evidence.judge_reasoning: EXCEPT WITH RESPECT TO (i) A PARTY'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS, (ii) A BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY, OR (iii) A PARTY'S WILLFUL MISCONDUCT OR GROSS NEGLIGENCE
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: EXCEPT WITH RESPECT TO (i) A PARTY'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS, (ii) A BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY, OR (iii) A PARTY'S WILLFUL MISCONDUCT OR GROSS NEGLIGENCE

evidence.excerpt: it may fulfill all accepted purchase orders and quotations issued prior to the effective date of termination... trademark licenses shall terminate at the end of a six (6) month sell-off period applicable to Reseller's existing inventory
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'immediate cessation could cause losses & customer disruption'. Amendment adds 6-month sell-off period (exceeds GT's 90-day expectation).
evidence.judge_reasoning: it may fulfill all accepted purchase orders and quotations issued prior to the effective date of termination... trademark licenses shall terminate at the end of a six (6) month sell-off period applicable to Reseller's existing inventory
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: it may fulfill all accepted purchase orders and quotations issued prior to the effective date of termination... trademark licenses shall terminate at the end of a six (6) month sell-off period applicable to Reseller's existing inventory

evidence.excerpt: Vendor shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Reseller... from and against any and all claims... arising out of (a) any allegation that the Products infringe or misappropriate any patent, copyright, trademark, trade secret, or other intellectual-property right; (b) product liability claims attributable to defects; or (c) Vendor's breach of its data-security obligations
evidence.reasoning: Risk table NCR correctly identifies missing indemnity. Comprehensive vendor indemnification for IP, product defects, and data breaches addresses all GT key elements.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Vendor shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Reseller... from and against any and all claims... arising out of (a) any allegation that the Products infringe or misappropriate any patent, copyright, trademark, trade secret, or other intellectual-property right; (b) product liability claims attributable to defects; or (c) Vendor's breach of its data-security obligations
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Vendor shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Reseller... from and against any and all claims... arising out of (a) any allegation that the Products infringe or misappropriate any patent, copyright, trademark, trade secret, or other intellectual-property right; (b) product liability claims attributable to defects; or (c) Vendor's breach of its data-security obligations

evidence.excerpt: Vendor shall comply with all applicable data-protection laws (including GDPR and CCPA) and maintain administrative, technical, and physical safeguards... Vendor shall notify Reseller within seventy-two (72) hours of discovering any data breach
evidence.reasoning: Risk table NCR correctly identifies contract 'silent on compliance with data-privacy laws'. Amendment adds comprehensive data protection with GDPR/CCPA and 72-hour breach notification.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Vendor shall comply with all applicable data-protection laws (including GDPR and CCPA) and maintain administrative, technical, and physical safeguards... Vendor shall notify Reseller within seventy-two (72) hours of discovering any data breach
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Vendor shall comply with all applicable data-protection laws (including GDPR and CCPA) and maintain administrative, technical, and physical safeguards... Vendor shall notify Reseller within seventy-two (72) hours of discovering any data breach

evidence.excerpt: Vendor shall provide second-level technical support to Reseller in accordance with the Service Level Addendum attached hereto as Exhibit C... Severity 1: Response within 2 hours; resolution or acceptable workaround within 8 hours... Service Credits: 2% credit for SLA breaches
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'no Vendor service-level commitment' at 7.2. Comprehensive SLA exhibit with tiered response times and service credits addresses all GT key elements.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Vendor shall provide second-level technical support to Reseller in accordance with the Service Level Addendum attached hereto as Exhibit C... Severity 1: Response within 2 hours; resolution or acceptable workaround within 8 hours... Service Credits: 2% credit for SLA breaches
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Vendor shall provide second-level technical support to Reseller in accordance with the Service Level Addendum attached hereto as Exhibit C... Severity 1: Response within 2 hours; resolution or acceptable workaround within 8 hours... Service Credits: 2% credit for SLA breaches

gt_evaluations.issue: Support SLAs Missing - No Service Level Commitments

additional_issues.notes: References Exhibit A, which is blank; without the list the scope of Products is uncertain.
Territory is limited to the U.S. & Canada; no clarity on online or cross-border sales to customers with global operations.
30-day net is acceptable, but 1.5% monthly interest is 18% APR, high in some jurisdictions.
Vendor can alter credit limits unilaterally; may cripple Reseller’s ability to fulfill deals.
Prohibits modifications, even minor localization; may hinder marketing effectiveness.
Vendor provides training but no service-level standard (frequency, format, cost).
Quarterly pipeline disclosure may include confidential customer information; no confidentiality carve-out.
Obligations expire after 3 years; trade secrets may need perpetual protection.
Only “performance” warranty; no IP non-infringement warranty.
Mutual exclusion is fine, but no carve-outs for indemnity, confidentiality, or willful misconduct.
No requirement for Vendor to maintain errors & omissions / cyber liability cover; exposes Reseller.
Prohibits assignment without consent; hampers corporate restructuring.

An empty exhibit renders the definition of “Products” uncertain, exposing Reseller to the risk of unintentionally selling unapproved items or losing the right to sell new releases. A populated exhibit

The addition allows Pacific Tech to accommodate global customers headquartered in the Territory and operate modern e-commerce channels without breaching territorial limits, while still respecting Vend
Adds concrete lead-registration and price-protection measures to mitigate channel conflict, encouraging Reseller investment in demand generation while preserving Vendor’s overall non-exclusive model.
Shifts legal risk of the EULA’s enforceability and content back to Vendor, who controls the EULA language, thereby protecting Reseller from downstream litigation exposure.
Introduces rational limits on frequency and extends notice, allowing Reseller to manage customer quotations and forecast margins with reasonable certainty.
Protects Reseller from financial exposure on outstanding quotes already provided to customers.
Aligns interest rate with usury limits and industry norms, preventing unenforceable or excessive charges.
Ensures operational continuity by providing notice and a dialogue mechanism before credit restrictions take effect.
Provides flexibility for localization and campaign tailoring while preserving Vendor brand integrity.
Adds a measurable standard and no-cost commitment, ensuring adequate enablement for Reseller’s team.
Anchors Vendor’s support obligations to concrete metrics, improving customer satisfaction and reducing Reseller support costs.
Limits sensitive detail and makes data share subject to existing confidentiality protections.
Provides Reseller with an exit path if market conditions change, while giving Vendor revenue-planning certainty for the first year.
Enables orderly wind-down, avoids stranded inventory, and clarifies survival of critical protections.
Aligns confidentiality term with industry best practice and perpetual protection for trade secrets, mitigating disclosure risk.
Provides critical IP non-infringement assurance which is standard in software distribution agreements.
Prevents Vendor from disavowing its newly added indemnity and IP warranty obligations via the disclaimer.
Ensures meaningful remedies remain for the most serious breaches.
Creates a mutual, balanced cap, carving out serious misconduct, thus aligning risk profiles.
Establishes customary, balanced indemnity structure protecting Reseller from key risks. Position: Add as new Article 14 immediately following Article 13.
Adds standard relief for unforeseeable events, preserving the relationship during crises. Position: Insert immediately after new Article 14.
Addresses statutory compliance obligations and reputational risk arising from data breaches. Position: Insert after Article 15.
Ensures Vendor has financial resources to cover product and data-related claims, indirectly protecting Reseller. Position: Insert after Article 16.
Gives Reseller enforceable metrics and remedies for support performance, enabling consistent customer experience. Position: Add as new Exhibit C.
Aligns governing law with Reseller’s domicile, reducing travel cost and improving predictability of legal outcomes.
Moves venue to Reseller’s home state and allows virtual hearings, lowering dispute-resolution friction and cost.
Provides operational flexibility for corporate restructuring and affiliate transactions while preserving the other Party’s protections.
